Every now andthen I like to give this program a kind of MItaly looks at
America'* aspect* I believe It Is important for Americans to know how they and
their country are regarded abroad* And I think most Americans are eager for such

Today’s version of “Italy looks at America*1 should b© more scientific than
my previous efforts on this theme* It is not based on interviews with Italian
ooliticlans or so-called “opinion leaders** It consists of results of a oubllc
opinion poll, based on a scientific sample, of the whole Italian population*
For all its faults, and despite some conspicuous failures, the public opinion
poll, based on a scientific sample, remains the most practical device we have for
measuring national attitudes on public questions* I mean that the poll is the
best means we have short of actual elections, held on specific issues*
In America, we know that despite their failures to predict accurately the
result of our 1948 presidential election, the polls were back in the picture ae
strong as over in 1952* .Popular Interest In them seemed as high as ever*
Well, popular interest in nubile opinion polling seems high In Italy, too*

PQXA starts out by explaining a scientific polling sample* It s?iys that a

3ut let’s get on to the results of the first poll — the one on Italian
attitudes toward America and Americans.
As its first question, PQXA asked Italians; “Do you have greater sympathy
for the British, the Americans* the Germans or the French? And in what order of
preference would you put thee?**
Fifty six per cent of the Italians polled said they were most sympathetic to
Americana. Eighteen per cent listed us in second place; ten percent in third.
Only six per cent listed the Americans last* Another ten per cent gave us no
